+
+Building a native executable requires using a distribution of GraalVM.

+
+* Mandrel is a downstream distribution of the Oracle GraalVM community edition.
+Mandrel's main goal is to provide a way to build native executables specifically designed to support Quarkus.
+

+They support the same capabilities to build native executables as Oracle GraalVM,
+with no significant changes to functionality.
+Notably, they do not include support for polyglot programming.

+This means that it does not profit from a few small enhancements that Oracle have added to the version of OpenJDK used to build their own GraalVM downloads.
+
+* Mandrel is only available for projects that can be compiled with Java 11.
+If you are using Java 8,
+you should consider using Oracle GraalVM instead.
+
+* Mandrel is currently only recommended for containerized environments.
+If you are building native executables for macOS or Windows,
+you should consider using Oracle GraalVM instead.
+Building for bare metal Linux is possible,
+with details available in the https://github.com/graalvm/mandrel/blob/master/README-Mandrel.md[Mandrel README]
+and https://github.com/graalvm/mandrel/releases[Mandrel releases].
+
+The prerequisites vary slightly depending on whether you are using Oracle GraalVM or Mandrel.
+
+== Prerequisites for Mandrel
+
+To complete this guide using Mandrel, you need:
+
+* less than 15 minutes
+* an IDE
+* JDK 11 installed with `JAVA_HOME` configured appropriately
+* A working container runtime (Docker, podman)
+* The code of the application developed in the link:getting-started[Getting Started Guide].

nodes.bodyText:
It's not required. But it's convenient. If you don't want containerized, you can just install a mandrel release from here and run with it (by pointing GRAALVM_HOME to the install): https://github.com/graalvm/mandrel/releases
We say that, because on Mac and Windows you can use the container to produce linux native images and deploy on Linux as no Windows and Mac community builds exist.
We only provide Linux builds only so far. If somebody steps in to do Mac and Windows community builds even better. It probably won't be us doing those (in the foreseeable future). Note that for Mac builds one would have to do OpenJDK 11u vanilla mac builds too or use some other base JDK which would open up the Mac build to a different class of problems.
